docs.lead_paragraph: HIRAM CHIREL is executive director of the 1,400-member New York State Podiatric Medical Association, the nation's largest state organization of foot specialists. In February the group voted to join the nation's first labor union for doctors, the First National Guild for Health Care Providers of the Lower Extremities. The move is an attempt to increase their influence against what the doctors see as restrictive rules imposed by managed care associations. Dr. Chirel, 66, was a president and board member of the medical association before becoming its executive director. He received his Doctor of Podiatric Medicine degree in 1956 from the New York College of Podiatric Medicine, and served on the faculty there as well as at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Dr. Chirel and his wife, Elba, also a podiatric physician and who is president of the Nassau County Podiatric Medical Association, live in Port Washington. They have two grown children. Q. The idea of doctors becoming unionized seems kind of strange.

docs.lead_paragraph: DEER stroll across front lawns and backyards in suburbs around the state, nibbling on flowers and shrubs, munching garden vegetables. The combination of increasing wooded areas, available food, and the relative paucity of predators has caused the state's deer population to explode to 55,000; there are thought to have been only about a dozen deer in the state at the turn of the century. But deer are more than suburban interlopers. As primary hosts for adult black-legged ticks they are major factors in the spread of Lyme disease. Now, some scientists hope they will also become a key to widespread prevention of the disease, as carriers of tick-deadly pesticides. ''Ticks are dependent on deer for reproduction. If they don't feed on deer, they can't reproduce,'' explained Dr. Durland Fish, a research scientist at Yale School of Medicine.Based on population, Connecticut has the highest statewide rate of Lyme disease in the country. Last year, there were 3,104 reported cases in the state out of a record-high 16,461 nationwide, according to the Federal Centers for Disease Control.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Long Island girl is nearly 15 years old, and she has been taking Prozac since she was 5. Before Prozac, she was a mess. She could not be left alone, even for minutes. Strangers terrified her, and she was obsessed by thoughts that her parents were dying or burglars were breaking into her house. Conventional therapy failed, said the girl's mother, who spoke on the condition that she and her daughter not be identified.

docs.lead_paragraph: Clinton Administration officials say they will soon propose a comprehensive Federal law to protect the privacy of medical records, to let consumers inspect their own files and to punish any unauthorized disclosures of personal data by hospitals, insurers, health plans or drug companies. The measure would establish minimum Federal standards to control the use of such information in the era of managed care, when insurance companies and health maintenance organizations have the ability and, in many cases, a financial incentive to collect and sell data revealing the most intimate secrets of millions of patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: For all Washington's celebratory mood over the nation's first major tax cut in 16 years, Congress and the Clinton Administration hardly issued an open invitation to the party. Rather than an across-the-board tax cut, the $96 billion package is a series of narrowly focused measures intended to achieve specific goals. How much you benefit depends on your personal circumstances. Here is a guide to achieving key financial objectives under the new rules. IN theory, the new budget law will create a supermarket of health insurance options for older Americans. Today, most people 65 and older are in the standard Medicare program, which pays a separate fee for each service. The new law creates a parallel ''Medicare+Choice'' program, with several alternatives.

docs.lead_paragraph: IF you are among the millions of Americans worried about being able to retire in comfort, you may want to pay close attention to the strike that began Monday at United Parcel Service and the tentative settlement the same day of the steel industry's longest strike ever, at Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel. Pensions were the core issue at Wheeling-Pittsburgh and are the No. 2 issue in the U.P.S. talks. And at companies from Continental Airlines to Rochester Telephone, workers are telling unions that pension benefits are almost as important to them as wages.

headline.main: Pension Concerns Move to the Picket Line
